ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Matt Decker was beyond helpful as a TA. He was willing to spend time troubleshooting assignments even outside of TA hours. What a great guy.The assignments were frequently frustrating. I didn't find it helpful to do something several times incorrectly before finally finding the small error I had made, as it tended to reinforce the wrong way of doing things.

This course was a lot of work, but it was well worth it. Dana presents the material very clearly, but you can only really learn the program by using it, hitting walls, and figuring out ways around them.
Amazing course. The instructor and TA both were very helpful and the assignments really force you to think and make sure that you understand the material.

7A. Dana is an excellent professor. He gradually brings us in to a program with the assumption that you don't know anything. This makes the material seem very accessible, even though it is challenging to use. He was more responsive than almost any professor I've ever had ever, and he really worked hard to answer questions and help us understand the material.7B. Matt Decker should receive the award for Most Patient and Helpful TA in the Universe. His ability to sit with a frustrated student and answer their questions was unwavering. He was always available, willing to meet with people outside of his (extensive) office hours, and he was never annoyed (or at least visibly so), even when he was getting peppered with the same questions over and over again while he was trying to finish his own work. I've never seen a person so happy to be helping other people understand a thing like GIS. Amazing.

I learned a tremendous amount about a topic in which I came in knowing nothing. This course was ridiculously frustrating from the onset, but it was designed this way. I realized at the end that I had learned quite a bit. I never realized that I was actually learning while I was actually taking the course.

Great instructor and great opportunity for learning in this class. the one thing i didn't like about theclass was the competitive prodding that the instructor engages in--publishing people's grades and comparing our work to UPenn students' work. This cultivates an intensity and a competitiveness that can obscure learning objectives.
Question 4: This class takes a lot of time and patience.

Q1: The instructors hand-outs were truly impressive, and will be saved for many years to come. These alone made the course worth taking.Q2: The instructor was very clear and methodical in his teaching style. The pace was excellent, and he made it possible for all students to stay on track conceptually.Q4: See Q13
Both Dana and Matt were amazing resources. They were above and beyond helpful with questions--even encouraging communication and questions!
Matt, the TA, was really helpful! I wouldn't have gotten through the course without him.
The support was phenomenal. Both Dana and Matt were incredibly accessible and knowledgeable. I also really appreciated the regularity and reliability of the syllabus.
GIS is really an invaluable tool, the handouts are a great resource to have both for the class and to keep for the future, and the instructor is very good at explaining the software.
Working on assignment and finally having that light-bulb go off in your head where everything clicks and you finally figure out what you have to do. It's a beautiful thing.
The instructor is very intentional in his teaching and is responsive to student's questions. There is a lot to learn about the software, but both the professor and the TA were available to help.

The fact that I really feel like I learned how to use this complex and totally useful program. I have already used GIS to make maps for a client I've been consulting for, and the work has gone into proposals for projects in New York City.
great skills-building coursegreat professorgreat assignments to practice concepts
The in-depth readings/course material and immediately applicable skills.
clarity of instruction
Having a hands on approach to using the software and a professor that is very willing to assist students.
This course was very well organized and well taught.
We learnt to use Arcmap that is one of the most powerful tool in order to show in a map thing such as environmental impact, population growth, relationship between variables and so on.
Getting to know all the GIS tools and playing around with the interface.

The best part about this course was gaining enough proficiency to be able to continue to develop skills in modeling on one's own. That is, I learned enough of the basics that I now know how, where, and what to look for in further developing my abilities. I appreciated also that the individual skills were set into a broader ArcGIS context, helping me to understand how the various programs worked together, and how the technical facets stem from past historical developments.Other than the time commitment and grading scheme (see Q13), this was a wonderful class that provided hands-on, practical skills to be used in the real world. I am so thankful that I took it, and will absolutely take the complimentary raster-based class. The delivery, resources, and assignments were all significant contributors to my learning.
All the help from the TA during office hours. Homeworks are very time demanding and it was nice being able to receive immediate help from the TA while in the computer lab.
Dana is a terrific lecturer and teacher. He made learning GIS fun and interesting.
The assignments were useful because you have to use the program to learn it. The instructor provided clear answers to questions asked during class.

Dana's incredible descriptions of the concepts, and obvious love for the material. Dana's flexibility on assignment deadlines, and (generally) his focus on getting people to understand GIS really well through different means (repetition, the tutorials, creative assignments, etc)
Mastery of a new skill

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: If only ArcMap were not so finicky. It could also be frustrating not knowing by what criteria the professor was grading assignments.
The homework assignments should involve less reading between the lines. It is reasonable for assignments to be time consuming and challenging, but it should be clear what is being asked.
Nothing that I can think of.
Not a thing. The homework was maddeningly difficult, but by screwing up a million times, I learned how to use the program. So good (in hindsight).
it's a lot of work

Too challenging of a question to answer. The professor was purposefully frustrating and confusing in order to make us learn better. This was a pain throughout the semester but in the end it was valuable and I appreciate it. If you had asked me this question two months ago I would tell the professor to be more direct, but I would no longer say this.
none

The professor dangled the curve in front of us as a motivational tool but I think this caused students an unnecessary amount of anxiety.Sometimes I had difficulty understanding exactly what was expected from assignments (eg. the need to point out problems in the Moose assignment and how to display results of biome assignment).
I tended to enjoy assignments the most when they were of a very practical nature.
The "tricks" hidden in each assignment. I would rather feel like I get it and learn more tools than take extra time trying to solve these tricks.

The most frustrating part about this course was that the professor had open-ended homework assignments for which he did not provide a rubric or hit-list of which skills we were supposed to be using and demonstrating a proficiency with. The issue is not the open-endedness, but the fact that once the assignments were turned in, the professor would then grade them on a very specific set of criteria. If the students had known which specific criteria he wanted us to aim for, then many of us would have had greater success on the assignments. It seemed rather unfair, really, that we would be left to explore and present our work according to general guidelines, while be evaluated on a secret set of specific guidelines. This amounted to students trying to guess what it was that the professor wanted to see.While I do like the base concept of open-ended assignments, this course demanded an excessive amount of time for some of us who did not have prior modeling experience. If the grading criteria for eachassignment were made available to students, and an imposed time-limit was set for assignments, I think more students would enjoy this class. As it was, my sense from working with peers was that this class fell into love-hate status. The skills are wonderful and I didn't talk to any students who disliked the subject matter. But, the time commitment was so great that some of the fun of learning to manipulate data in a new program was lost. In this way, I think the positive sides of the course did not impassion the students to as great a degree as is possible. Perhaps some slightly modified approach could be adopted in the future.

This course was so much more stressful and frustrating than it needed to be. The grading criteria were opaque and I honestly never knew whether I would get an 8 or a 2 on any given assignment. That doesn't exactly inspire me to put in more than the minimal amount of effort required to make something I could hand in. Hiding tricks and errors in the problem set that students have to be lucky enough to catch (or to hear about because they were in the computer lab a the right time) just makes students frustrated. It seems to have discouraged people from taking further classes about arcGIS.

There is a lot of 'point chasing' that goes on. Dana dangles points in front of students, and is sometimes sneaky in hiding issues with the data/problem in the assignment which leads to student energy wasted on trying to figure out what he wants instead of learning the material really well. Dana is occasionally condescending to students, which is not appreciated.
It's nice to see something that has been perfected over time; I truly have no suggestions for improvement. (A rarity!)

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: FANTASTIC!

I contacted both, and as I mentioned, they were both awesome. Dana and Matt both responded to emails very quickly, and Matt was often in the computer lab for much longer than his scheduled office hours.
I emailed Dana a few times and got helpful responses very quickly. I also used Matt Decker, the TA, as a resource quite frequently, and also found him to be extremely knowledgeable.
I contacted both the TA and the professor and both were very responsive.
MORE AMAZING THAN ANY CLASS EVER. I don't think you could find a pair of people more available to help students than Dana and Matt.

Both the instructor and the TA went to great effort to be available to the students, and both were extremely responsive to questions. It was very helpful to be able to reach out to both and know that a response would be forthcoming promptly.
terrific

The instructor answer emails within a day or so and that was nice. Typically emails were terse but, for the most part, to the point and helpful.The TA was amazingly helpful and was always willing to provide support and advice to a lab full of students. A++

fantastic. Matt always made himself available and responded patiently to questions and concerns. Great balance of expertise and encouragement; he would not simply give out answers but rather push you to figure out solutions--asking probing questions or offering reminders of when and where we might have encountered simliar problems before. kudos.
Adequate

Both the professor and the TA were very responsive to my questions. Sometimes they gave conflicting information/instructions (eg. TA said re-submissions did not have to be a completely new assignment but prof said they did).
They both were always available to help and to solve any doubt
Very available/high quality.
TA was amazing and went above and beyond the call of duty and his office hours. The professor also was good and returning emails at all hours of the day.

The instructor and TA were both available by email. The instructor adopted a socratic method, or "coyote-teaching" approach of leading students with questions and hints. I appreciated this, and felt that it contributed positively to my own learning. The TA was most assistive during office hours, but I wish that both the TA and the professor had greater availability. Not necessarily more hours, though that would be nice, but instead just a wider variety of days and times. I was rarely available during any of the office hours, which made acquiring help very challenging.
Exceptional. The best I have ever experienced. Thank you Matt Decker!
Both Matt and Dana are very available and responsive.
The TA is amazing and wonderful and I think everyone in the class would agree. The instructor responded quickly to emails, which was nice.
Matt and Dana are SO available, responsive, and helpful. it was amazing. Dana pings back emails with light speed. You just have to be careful to explain the issue really well.

Excellent--both were available via email constantly, and I frequented Matt's office hours in the computer lab. Their availability was really surprising to me and makes me appreciate the quality of courses taught at FES, even as this is my second year here.
Both were available and very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I took a GIS course undergrad, but never felt like I really got a sold grip on it. I am interested in Land-Use planning and feel that having a GIS background is definitely necessary.

I spent my entire first year taking classes based in theory, which was valuable to me, but hard to convert into real professional skills. This class was one that let me learn a real skill that can carry over to other projects and professions.

My interests are in land conservation, and the utilization of GIS is a critical skill-set to have in this field. This course gave me a practical skill-set that will be helpful as I transition back to the professional world.
great opportunity to gain skills that might be necessary for land-based conservation work
This course is not required. However, my project wouldn't be possible without the skills I have gained and so I am grateful for the quality of the material I was taught.
Disasters should be looked at spatially, especially with a unique tool such as ArcMap.
I am currently planning research that will utilize GIS for data processing and inference. This course was an essential piece of my target skill set that will be employed in the near future.
As someone focused on water resource management, I believe this class will help with my future jobs.

Honestly I am not sure. I wish we had talked more about the application of this program in different fields- conservation, urban planning, park management, ect. When the time came to think of a project, I wasn't sure where to find data because I didn't have a good idea of what people actually used what GIS data for.
Useful skill for natural resource professionals, future work
I am not sure how I will use this course but I am glad that I took it, if only to learn about what GIS is capable of.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Skillz.
To learn GIS.
SKILLZ
See above - I took this class to develop a practical skill-set that will be extremely beneficial in finding a job in the land conservation field as I transition back to the professional world.
great opportunity to gain skills that might be necessary for land-based conservation work
To do good research.
To obtain a marketable skill to employers and to analyze my research data.
I took it because I wanted to learn a tool that allow me to show in a map any environmental change.
I believe it is an essential skill to have in the professional world.
I wanted a refresher in how to use GIS.
As above... I took this course to prepare myself for future research, and to acquire an in-demand skill.
Valuable skill to know. Something concrete that I can put on my resume.
To hone my GIS skills.
I was told by a few people and many job postings that it is very useful when working in environmental science and conservation. I wanted to learn skills to put on my resume.
i want a hard skill on my resume. I want to be able to take data and interpret it myself instead of relying on information/analysis from others
Interest
To learn about GIS which I had heard so much about but never explored before.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, I gained a much better understanding of vector-based analyses, and feel much more comfortable with the prospect of using the program to solve problems.
Yes

Absolutely. This course is unique in that it doesn't give you a step by step procedure to take, but rather gives you the tools and makes you figure out when to use them. This is certainly the best way to make sure you have a true understanding.
I learned more about GIS than I thought I would.
Yes, I came away with a solid understanding of vector-based GIS.
yes
...exceeded...usually...when I wasn't frustrated
yes.
yes
Yes.
yes.
Yes.
In terms of what I learned, this course absolutely lived up to my expectations. I came into it with zero knowledge of GIS modeling, and left with a basic but formidable skill set.
Yes. While the work load was hard, I learned a lot from homework assignments.
Absolutely. A terrific course. I learned a lot.
I learned a lot in the class but wish we talked more about what kind of problems are commonly solved with arcGIS.
yes
Yes, exceeded
Yes, I learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
I got more out of it that I expected.
More than.
Yes, I developed the skills to be a proficient user of GIS
yes
See question 17
yes.
yes
Yes.
This course is one of the best of the FES courses.
yes.
Yes.
Yes. I left with more skills and conceptual understanding than I had imagined I would have.
Yes.
95%. we learned the basics so well, i wonder if it would have been better not to dwell on simple things at the beginning of the course so that we could learn more analysis tools.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: n/a
We were often asked to work on our own, so work groups, which would have been welcomed, were not allowed.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Start the homework early and give yourself limits--it is very easy to spend many more hours than you intended. Take advantage of the support network. Take advantage of the fact that homework submissions are displayed for perusal--people did really interesting things with assignments that I never though of, so looking at other people's work was a really good way for me to get a better sense of the program's possibilities.
If you want to fully understand what is being asked of you, you need to go to office hours to ask questions, or email the instructor. The assignments are rarely completely straightforward.
Start the assignments early. If you put them off to last minute to may get very frustrated if something doesn't work.
Do the tutorials, and start the assignments early in the week so you have ample time to get help should you need it.

Be prepared for the homework to take a long time, but do know that there is a point at which you get diminishing returns. You could spend 15 hours on a homework assignment, but you probably won't do any better than the people who spent 5 or 6 hours.

Take advantage of the handouts, utilize the tutorials, and reach out to the professor or TA with questions. It is of course beneficial to start the assignments earlier rather than later - try to do the assignments while the material from class is still fresh.
Keep working hard. It's a pain but worth it.
start your homework assignment right after class, if you can, while the relevant discussion and demonstration is fresh in your mind. work in the lab during TA hours
Be prepared to commit a lot of time every week towards homework.
This course is a lot of work. Assignments can be frustrating but rewarding.

Before this course I did not work ever in Map, thus by this course was my first time using map, so do not feel afraid if you did not work with maps before.The arcmap is one of the most powerful tools in order to show any environmental impact or change.I highly recommend this course.
Spend time with the tutorials and use the handouts.
Know this course will take alot of time and energy.

1.) Read the assignments VERY carefully, and try to address all of the subtleties in the the text description of what you are supposed to do. The professor chooses his words carefully, so you would do best to follow his direction.2.) Review others assignments to see what you are missing, and to get ideas for the next assignments.3.) Expect to spend 20+/- hours a week on each assignment.4.) Like any program, ArcGIS can be insanely frustrating. The beginning seems most confusing, since it is hard to understand and access even basic tools. In time, this challenge fades and you are faced with more complex versions of the same. The program is so sophisticated that it can do pretty much everything you can imagine. So over time, the frustration falls in trying to figure out how to do what it is that you are imagining.5.) The TA was very helpful in a practical way - visit him/her.6.) It is helpful to have a laptop in class such that you can executethe tutorial assignments (the first part of every homework assignment) in class, as the instructor leads everyone through it. This saves 1+/- hour at home.7.) Do the assignment as soon after the class as you can. I had class on thursday, and would do the assignment thursday, friday, and saturday. If you wait too long, you might forget the technical pieces of the problem, thereby increasing the time commitment and the frustration.8.) This is part one of two. Those who are really interested in GIS should plan to take both this and the rast-based course.
Start your homework early and if you get stumped, seek help immediately instead of waiting until you are thoroughly frustrated.

Work in groups or with a partner- the assignments that I learned the most from doing were the ones where I worked with another person and we tried different tools to get the same result. That way we both learned more that we would have separately.

Take advantage of Dana's amazing availability and ability to instruct. Don't be put off by his occasional grumpiness. DO NOT I REPEAT DO NOT wait until wednesday to start the assignment. give yourself 9 hours over three days, not including the day it's due, to complete the assignment. best case scenario, start it the second the class in which he's teaching the material is over.
Print off the handouts Dana makes available on Classesv2, go to office hours
Start your work early
